user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
```c
bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /*
     * Check if the obj_id is both valid and matches
     * the specified creator_id
     */
    return (OS_ObjectIdIsValid(obj->active_id) && (OS_ObjectIdEqual(filter->creator_id, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) ||
                                                   OS_ObjectIdEqual(obj->creator, filter->creator_id)));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
typedef struct
{
    osal_id_t        creator_id;
    OS_ArgCallback_t user_callback;
    void *           user_arg;
} OS_creator_filter_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline bool OS_ObjectIdIsValid(osal_id_t object_id)
{
    osal_objtype_t objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id);
    return (objtype > OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED && objtype < OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER);
}
...
static inline bool OS_ObjectIdEqual(osal_id_t object_id1, osal_id_t object_id2)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id1) == OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id2));
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found. Reasoning:
- The function parameters are: void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj. Rule 17.8 prohibits modifying the parameter variables (e.g., assigning to ref/token/obj); it allows modifying the object pointed to by a pointer parameter, but not the pointer itself.
- The only use of ref is to initialize a local pointer: OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref; this assigns the parameter value to a local variable and does not modify the parameter itself.
- The obj parameter is a pointer to const and is only read (obj->active_id and obj->creator); no modification of the pointed-to object occurs.
- token is unused in the function (no modification).
- Called helpers (OS_ObjectIdIsValid, OS_ObjectIdEqual) take osal_id_t by value and do not modify the function parameters.
- Macros/constants (e.g., OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) and inline helpers shown do not perform modifications of the parameters.
Therefore there are no occurrences in this function that violate Rule 17.8.
